newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-AWB Report-Australia wheat exports on track.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-AWB Report-Australia wheat exports on track.

text.p: Australia and Canada shared the bulk of a Saudi Arabian purchase of 500,000 tonnes of wheat last week at prices reported at A$163.00 a tonne, the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) said in its weekly grain market report.
AWB sales to Sri Lanka and Turkey in the last week had been at prices very supportive of pool returns, it said.
Australia sold 50,000 tonnes of soft wheat to Sri Lanka at A$212.50 a tonne c and f for December shipment, it said.
Shipments to Turkey during October and November totalled 190,000 tonnes with an additional 60,000 tonnes due to be shipped in December, it said.
By the end of November, the AWB had shipped 1.7 million tonnes of wheat, the best start to a shipping season since market deregulation in 1989, it said.
The European Commission last week boosted wheat and barley subsidy prices slightly, with the wheat subsidy up to A$27.00 a tonne and the barley subsidy to A$47.00 a tonne, it said.
Argentine producers rejected trade claims last week that the total crop could reach 17.0 million tonnes, the AWB said.
The harvest was gathering pace around Australia with early deliveries made in Victoria last week, the board said.
Indications continued than usual quantities of small grains in this season's sample, the AWB said.
Bids for Prime Hard wheat fell by A$8.00-A$9.00 a tonne in New South Wales (NSW) and Queensland while in Victoria bids for the premium grades rose by A$4.00 a tonne.
Feed grain prices were particularly buoyant, it said.

Feeders anticipating ample supplies of feed wheat in Queensland had been disappointed and were now buying Australian Standard White, it said. Feed barley prices firmed by A$2.00 a tonne in Queensland and remained firm in NSW, the report said.

New crop sorghum in Queensland was trading well above export parity with bids up by A$2.00 a tonne, while in Victoria there has been a A$6.00 a tonne rise in triticale prices and a A$2.00 a tonne increase in winter wheat prices.
Canola continued to be volatile during the week with prices A$6.00 a tonne down to A$350.00 a tonne delivered Melbourne.
The AWB has replaced its indicator price with cash bids at all sites.
The estimated wheat crop remains at 21.0 million tonnes.
Wheat Shipping:
Latest Week Year to Date Previous Year
NOTE: Shipping year starts October 1.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
